awd_titl_txt: CSR: Small: Data Services for Reliable Crowdsensing in Urban Spaces
awd_abstract_narration:
This project develops theory and tools for reliable crowdsensing, aiming to significantly reduce infrastructure investment costs needed to turn urban spaces into future smart cities. Crowdsensing, for purposes of this project, refers to the utilization of the smartest asset in the city - the people - in sharing data on their environment, thereby reducing the need for expensive physical sensors. As an example and living testbed, the work builds a smart transportation application, offering a novel vehicular crowdsensing-based navigation service, called GreenGPS. The novelty of this service is in finding the most fuel-economic routes for drivers, as opposed to the shortest or fastest, saving 10-20% in energy costs according to initial tests.   

It is estimated that, today, 54% of the world population lives in cities. This percentage will increase to 66% by 2050. City dwellers are the primary stakeholders and beneficiaries of this project. They are the drivers in smart transportation applications, the survivors in disaster response scenarios, and the consumers in energy saving systems. They are in possession of increasingly many sensing platforms, such as cameras, GPS devices, Internet-connected cars, smartphones, and activity monitoring wearable devices. By building the tools that broadly enable smart city applications to rely on opt-in human stakeholders, the project can leverage the pool of their existing sensors to facilitate informed city-scale decision-making in areas like traffic flow, energy consumption, or post-disaster management. A key analytic contribution lies in developing the mathematical foundations for attainment of information reliability guarantees on top of the generally unreliable data that human sources may provide. The project also includes creating educational modules for different levels of undergraduate and graduate instruction on the topic of next generation crowdsensing systems. Combining research and education, the project aims to facilitate evolution of urban spaces into smart cities, while educating future decision-makers and workforce on theory and tools underlying the transition.

por.por_cntn:
Modern city dwellers are in possession of increasingly many sensing platforms, such as cameras, GPS devices, Internet-connected cars, smartphones, smart watches, wireless energy metering systems, and activity monitoring wearables. To reduce the cost of infrastructure investment and facilitate retrofitting, new Smart City and Internet-of-Things applications will increasingly exploit these existing sensors in creative ways to make inferences about physical states of interest, such as traffic flow, energy consumption, or post-disaster damage; a practice that we call crowdsensing. The project developed theory and tools for reliable crowdsensing in urban spaces. The scientific contribution lies in the attainment of reliability guarantees on top of the generally unreliable data and sources that might be expected in large-scale smart city and Internet-of-Things (IoT) scenarios.

The theory and tools developed in this project enable a myriad of important applications, from increasing the efficacy of disaster response to attaining greener transportation and improving real-time mapping of city flows. In these applications, significant amounts of data pour-in from a multitude of unvetted sources, yet reliable conclusions must be extracted from the data streams.

From an analytical standpoint, the project significantly contributed to the unification of the foundations of sensing (and data fusion) across human and physical components. Theory, models, and algorithms were developed that allow viewing social/online media as a form of sensors, giving rise to data fusion techniques that seamlessly integrate inputs from human and physical sources, while offering analytically-founded accuracy guarantees similar to those in physical signal fusion systems. The work allows distilling real-time physical and social data flows into actionable information to support improved decision-making.

To illustrate the potential benefits of results of this project, a crowdsensing service was developed, called GreenRoute that uses data collected from vehicles to model fuel consumption and advance green vehicular navigation. This service fine-tuned prior work of the primary investigator that aims to reduce the energy and carbon footprint of urban transportation. Simulation studies, carried out on a model of the City of Chicago, suggest that the service, if deployed in the city, can save over 17 million gallons of fuel per year.   Results of this project also support other applications that range from curbing the flow of disinformation on social media to improving resilience of information flow in defense contexts. A key underlying enabler of these applications lies in tools to distill more reliable information from large amounts of unreliable data.
